title: James Packer warns Crown Resorts to lift its Australian casinos game
text:
Crown Resorts director James Packer: "The capex we've spent in Australia hasn't delivered the returns we budgeted on." Reuters by Perry Williams Catie Low Billionaire James Packer has criticised the performance of Crown Resorts' Australian casinos, saying returns in the past few years had fallen short of expectations and it needed to improve its net profits for shareholders.
Mr Packer, who owns 50 per cent of Crown, said the casino operator had to improve its record in Australia.
"We have to get better at achieving an acceptable return on the capital expenditure we spend in Australia," Mr Packer told investors at Crown's annual general meeting in Melbourne on Wednesday. "The capex we've spent in Australia hasn't delivered the returns we budgeted on."
The casino magnate, who stepped down as Crown's chairman in August, said its Australian resorts could no longer hide behind the historical success of its Macau operations.
"Up until 2014 in Australia that was hidden by Macau's success," he said. "But net profit after tax is the number that matters and that will be down again this year because Macau hadn't stopped declining.
"If you look at Crown over the last four years up until fiscal 2014 the net profit growth came from Macau, not Australia."
Crown had earlier said its Australian mass market gaming revenue grew by 10 per cent in the past three months as it reassured investors it would devote more of its focus to growing the company's net profit after a mixed performance this year.
Revenue from its main floor gaming at its Melbourne and Perth casinos, which excludes VIP earnings, rose by 10 per cent for the period from July 1 to October 18 compared with the prior corresponding period.
 Its non-gaming revenue increased by 1 per cent and turnover growth in its high-roller business met expectations. But its CrownBet wagering brand has continued to incur start-up losses, despite revenue growth.
'Not without its challenges' Crown's newly installed chairman, Rob Rankin, told shareholders the company had challenges as it worked its way through a multibillion-dollar pipeline of projects spanning from Melbourne and Sydney through to Las Vegas and Macau.
"I am very positive about the future of this company, but it is not without its challenges, both locally and internationally," said Mr Rankin. "In particular, we will need to execute very well on our development pipeline to deliver acceptable and attractive returns. In other words, we will be more focused on maximising Crown's net profit after tax for the benefit of all shareholders."
Crown's net profit in 2015 fell 18 per cent to $525 million as an increase in corporate costs, a poor performance from Macau and moderate growth from its Perth casino weighed on revenues.
The Melbourne-based gaming giant said disappointing results from its Macau business have continued in the 2016 financial year, following declines in gross gaming revenue from the second half of 2015.
The Macau casino operator part-owned by Mr Packer's Crown Resorts will seek talks with lenders on the $US3.2 billion ($4.4 billion) Studio City casino after authorities approved just 250 gaming tables for the complex on Tuesday, dashing hopes it would meet a 400-table commitment.
However, Mr Rankin said the casino player was content with the long-term growth picture for Macau.
"While a lot has been said recently about the significant trading slowdown in Macau, in my mind this is short-sighted," said Mr Rankin.
"Macau is a market that has been beneficial to Crown and we have great faith in its long-term development. We should always remember that the Macau gaming market is still around five times the size of the market in Las Vegas and that last year, Macau accommodated 31.5 million visitors, the vast majority from the mainland."
Mr Rankin said Crown remained confident in the strength of China's economy, despite a recent slowdown, noting the country became the world's largest tourism market last year.
"I am an optimist when it comes to China's long-term future," said Mr Rankin. "Yes, there will be setbacks and this growth won't be linear, but we believe that the Chinese government will continue to support their economy, in order to lift more of its people out of poverty."
On Monday, Crown said it would use a $1.5 billion, 90-storey hotel and apartment complex in Melbourne's Southbank as a possible blueprint for a new luxury hotel brand to be rolled out among its other properties.
Crown shares rose 2.33 per cent to $11.84 in early trading on the ASX on Wednesday.
